stream_context.summary: Kaze works on a new ice/crystal-themed castle level, focusing on 3D modeling, bug fixing, and system refactoring. Key activities include resolving a critical collision bug by implementing per-level memory allocation, overhauling the in-game mirror system to be more flexible, and struggling with a persistent, emulator-only lighting bug. He also discusses his future release strategy, which involves eventually dropping emulator support to pursue hardware-specific optimizations.

development_findings.summary: Kaze plans a phased release: v1.0 for emulators and N64, followed by a v1.1 bug-fix patch. Subsequently, he intends to drop official emulator support to pursue N64-specific optimizations (like tri-strips) that are incompatible with current emulators, aiming for maximum performance on original hardware.
development_findings.quote: I will ditch emulator support entirely... Because supporting emulators makes the entire game run slower.

development_findings.summary: A persistent and difficult-to-diagnose bug causes ambient lighting to fail on emulators when a second light source is present. The issue does not occur on real N64 hardware, and Kaze is struggling to find the root cause.
development_findings.quote: ever since x3 we have one little bug in the game... if a second light source appears like the star over there, Mario's colors just go dark, the ambient just resets to zero.

development_findings.summary: Kaze refactored the hardcoded mirror system into a more flexible, data-driven one. The new system uses a struct to define the mirror's axis and range, significantly simplifying the process of adding new mirrors to levels.
development_findings.quote: Dude, this is gonna be the easiest system to add new murals ever.

development_findings.summary: Kaze encountered a critical collision bug due to an excessive number of triangles in a level. He resolved this by creating a per-level memory allocation system for collision surfaces, allowing different levels to have different memory limits.
development_findings.quote: I might have to change the allocation per level because this is unplayable.

development_findings.summary: Performance analysis reveals the primary bottleneck is the RSP (Reality Signal Processor), not the RDP. This finding, discovered with Sauraen, informs Kaze's strategy to focus on RSP-specific optimizations for performance gains.
development_findings.quote: The bottleneck is actually the rsp and not the rdp.

development_findings.summary: The game is incompatible with the well-known Mario 64 PC port due to its reliance on custom F3DEX3 microcode features and complex color combiners that the port does not support.

Kaze demonstrates an iterative level design process, getting a sudden 'vision' for a room to become a 'sea of monsters' and immediately beginning to modify the geometry to match the new creative direction.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes that for most applications, the choice of programming language (among reasonable options like C++, Rust, Java) is irrelevant, and that obsessing over the language choice is a 'skill issue' and a sign of a poor programmer.
context_findings.quote: if you care at all, like even just a little bit about which programming language you use, that is a very strong indicator that you're a terrible programmer.

context_findings.summary: Kaze's motivation to work harder and stream more frequently is directly tied to his new role as a father and the financial responsibility that comes with it.
context_findings.quote: I have a child now and I need more money. So hopefully there will be more streams.

context_findings.summary: Kaze detailed a sophisticated spear-phishing attempt where scammers, posing as advertisers, tried to trick him into running a malicious executable. His strict policy against running unknown executables prevented the attack.
context_findings.quote: I'm not downloading and running an exe file ever no matter how legit this looks.

context_findings.summary: Kaze confirms the game will be released as a patch file to be applied to a user-provided ROM, avoiding direct distribution of Nintendo's intellectual property. He acknowledges but does not endorse the inevitable creation of unauthorized physical cartridges sold by third parties.
context_findings.quote: I will release a patch that will contain only my own changes. And then you will be able to patch this patch onto an N64 ROM.

context_findings.summary: Kaze mentions his mother picking up his medication, followed by a brief chat discussion about bipolar meds and caffeine's effect on his anxiety, indicating personal health topics he is managing alongside development.

biobak.summary: Kaze humorously mentions the 'wrath of Biobak' as a motivation to fix misaligned textures, highlighting Biobak's high standards for visual precision and quality.
biobak.quote: Fix it now while you can. Before the wrath of Biobak murders me.

biobak.summary: Kaze states he needs to clean up his 3D level blockouts before handing them over to Biobak, indicating a workflow where Biobak is responsible for the final art and texturing pass.
biobak.quote: it's not insulting to Biobak when I pass this over.

badub.summary: Badub was not mentioned in this stream.

zeina.summary: Kaze links his increased motivation to work and stream more directly to his new responsibilities as a father, stating he needs more money now that he has a child with Zeina.
Zeina was present in the stream chat, engaging in lighthearted conversation with Kaze, including a request for a 'fat Yoshi plush'.

key_stories.title: The Spear-Phishing Attempt
key_stories.summary: Kaze recounted a sophisticated spear-phishing attempt by scammers posing as advertisers. His strict personal security rule of never running unknown executables allowed him to avoid the trap and subsequently collaborate with an anti-scam expert to pursue the perpetrators.
key_stories.challenge: A highly convincing scammer, posing as a legitimate advertiser for a 'web-free teaching school', attempted to get Kaze to run a malicious executable file under the guise of using a special video call app.
key_stories.process: Kaze became suspicious when asked to download an .exe file. He refused and insisted on Zoom. The scammers then sent a link to a fake Zoom website, confirming his suspicions and prompting him to investigate the identity they were using.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze's strict security policy prevented the attack. He then contacted the real person whose identity was stolen, who happened to be an anti-scam expert, and they are now working together to track the scammers.
key_stories.key_quote: I'm not downloading and running an exe file ever no matter how legit this looks.

key_stories.title: The Mirror System Refactor
key_stories.summary: To improve his workflow, Kaze completely refactored the game's mirror functionality. He replaced a rigid, hardcoded implementation with a flexible, data-driven system, making it vastly simpler to create and configure mirrors throughout the game.
key_stories.challenge: The original system for creating in-game mirrors was inflexible and likely required hardcoding for each instance, making it difficult and time-consuming to add new ones.
key_stories.process: Kaze designed a new data structure to hold mirror parameters like axis and position. He then rewrote the game's code to read from this struct, creating a universal, data-driven mirror object that he tested across multiple levels.
key_stories.outcome: The new system is far more flexible and computationally efficient. Adding new mirrors is now a simple matter of placing an object and setting its parameters, a significant improvement Kaze celebrated on stream.
key_stories.key_quote: Dude, this is gonna be the easiest system to add new murals ever.

key_stories.title: The Per-Level Collision Fix
key_stories.summary: When a complex new level kept crashing the game, Kaze diagnosed the issue as an overflow of the global collision memory pool. He solved the problem by engineering a new system for per-level memory allocation, allowing him to set custom limits for more demanding levels.
key_stories.challenge: A new, large level was unplayable because its geometry exceeded the game's global limit for collision data, causing the game to crash.
key_stories.process: Kaze identified that a single, game-wide memory pool for collision was insufficient. He modified the memory allocation code to create level-specific pools, allowing him to define a larger collision budget for this specific level without impacting others.
key_stories.outcome: The fix resolved the crash, making the level playable again. This architectural change provides more flexibility for designing future levels that may have varying complexity and resource needs.
key_stories.key_quote: I really have to think about a solution... I might have to change the allocation per level because this is unplayable.

open_questions.context: Kaze is struggling with a persistent lighting bug that only appears on emulators. When a second light source is active, ambient light disappears. He knows it's related to his emulator-specific 'x2' code but is unsure of the exact cause.
questions: What is the fundamental difference between your 'x2' (emulator) and 'x3' (console) lighting setup that causes this bug?
What are the next steps you'll take to debug this? Is it a blocker for the demo release?
Have you considered this might be an emulator inaccuracy you're fighting against, rather than a bug purely in your code?

open_questions.topic: Microcode Optimizations and Dropping Emulator Support
open_questions.context: Kaze plans to drop emulator support after version 1.1 to implement N64-specific optimizations like tri-strips. He states he needs to learn a lot about RSP microcode first and is waiting on work being done by Sauraen.
questions: What specific performance gains do you realistically expect from using tri-strips and other RSP optimizations?
Can you describe the learning curve for RSP microcode programming? What resources exist?
What is Sauraen's specific role in developing the F3DEX3 microcode, and how does your work depend on his progress?

open_questions.context: Kaze mentions needing to clean up his level 'blockouts' so they aren't 'insulting to Biobak' and fears the 'wrath of Biobak' over misaligned textures.
questions: Can you walk us through the collaborative workflow between you and Biobak? At what stage of completion does he typically take over a level?
